options.label: a
options.text: the superior mesenteric artery supplies all the transverse colon

options.label: b
options.text: the appendix is attached to the postero-medial surface of the caecum

options.label: c
options.text: the ascending colon is usually on a mesentery

options.label: d
options.text: the left colic flexure is higher than the right

options.label: e
options.text: the caecum is covered by peritoneum

explanation: The caecum is completely covered with peritoneum and the appendix is attached to its posteromedial surface. The transverse and sigmoid colon are usually on a mesentery. The superior mesenteric artery supplies the proximal two thirds of the transverse colon and the inferior mesenteric artery supplies the remainder

options.label: a
options.text: begins at the medial border of the first rib

options.label: b
options.text: is related to the brachial plexus cords

options.label: c
options.text: is divided into three parts by the pectoralis minor muscle

options.label: d
options.text: ends at the lower border of the teres minor

options.label: e
options.text: has an axillary sheath continuous with the prevertebral fascia

explanation: The axillary artery begins at the lateral border of the first rib and ends at the lower border of the teres major muscle. It is related to the cords of the brachial plexus and is enclosed in the axillary sheath, which is continuous with the prevertebral fascia

options.label: a
options.text: it is bounded medially by the lateral pterygoid plate

options.label: b
options.text: it communicates with the pterygopalatine fossa

options.label: c
options.text: it contains the mandibular nerve

options.label: d
options.text: the foramen spinosum lies in its roof

options.label: e
options.text: the foramen ovale lies in its roof

explanation: The infratemporal fossa is bounded medially by the lateral pterygoid plate and laterally by the ramus of the mandible. The foramen spinosum and ovale lie in the roof of the infratemporal fossa. The foramen spinosum transmits the middle meningeal artery, and the foramen ovale transmits the mandibular nerve. Medially, the infratemporal fossa communicates with the pterygo-palatine fossa

options.label: a
options.text: the head of the pancreas lies at the level of L3

options.label: b
options.text: lies posterior to the common bile duct

options.label: c
options.text: has a head which lies higher than the tail

options.label: d
options.text: lies anterior to the lesser sac

options.label: e
options.text: has the splenic vein running along its inferior border

explanation:
The pancreas lies on the posterior abdominal wall at the level L1, and its tail lies higher than the head. The tail of the pancreas lies in the lienorenal ligament, whereas the remainder of the gland is retroperitoneal.
The relations of the pancreas are:
Anteriorly - transverse colon, attachment of transverse mesocolon, lesser sac, stomach
Posteriorly - common bile duct, portal and splenic veins, IVC and aorta, origin of the superior mesenteric artery, left kidney and adrenal gland, psoas muscle, spleen

options.label: a
options.text: the right vagus nerve passes through the caval opening

options.label: b
options.text: the oesophageal hiatus lies at the level T12

options.label: c
options.text: it receives a blood supply from aortic branches

options.label: d
options.text: it is pierced by the thoracic duct

options.label: e
options.text: it arises in part from slips from the lower six costal cartilages

explanation:
The diaphragm originates from:
(1) the medial arcuate ligament
(2) the lateral arcuate ligament
(3) slips from the lower six costal cartilages
(4) slips from the posterior xiphisternum surface
(5) central tendon

The diaphragm has three main openings. The aortic opening at the level T12 transmits the aorta, thoracic duct, and azygos vein. The esophageal opening at the level T10 transmits the esophagus, vagal trunks, branches of the left gastric artery, veins, and lymphatics. The caval opening at the level T8 transmits the IVC and the right phrenic nerve.
The diaphragm is supplied by inferior phrenic arteries from the aorta and the intercostal arteries

options.label: a
options.text: the maxilla

options.label: b
options.text: the occipital bone

options.label: c
options.text: the sphenoid bone

options.label: d
options.text: the frontal bone

options.label: e
options.text: the temporal bone

options.label: a
options.text: begins at the level C4

options.label: b
options.text: is 10 cm long

options.label: c
options.text: has a diameter of 1cm

options.label: d
options.text: consists of complete cartilage rings

options.label: e
options.text: lies anterior to the recurrent laryngeal nerve

explanation: The trachea begins at the level C6 and extends to the level T5. It is 15cms long, 2cm in diameter and is composed of incomplete cartilage rings. The relations of the cervical course of the trachea are: Anteriorly - isthmus of thyroid, inferior thyroid veins, sternohyoid and sternothyroid muscle. Posteriorly - esophagus, recurrent laryngeal nerves. Laterally - thyroid gland, common carotid artery. The relations of the thoracic course of the trachea are: Anteriorly - left brachiocephalic vein, brachiocephalic and left common carotid artery, arch of aorta, sternum, thymus. Posteriorly - esophagus and left recurrent laryngeal nerve. Right side - azygos vein, right vagus nerve, and pleura. Left side - arch of the aorta, left common carotid and left subclavian arteries, left vagus and phrenic nerves, pleura

options.label: a
options.text: has a triangular base

options.label: b
options.text: is ovoid in shape when full

options.label: c
options.text: neck rests on the prostate

options.label: d
options.text: trigone has a trabeculated surface

options.label: e
options.text: is intraperitoneal

explanation: The empty bladder has a pyramidal shape and is described as having an apex, base, superior surface, two inferolateral surfaces, and a neck. The base is triangular, and the area of mucous membrane on the internal surface of the base is called the trigone. The trigone has a smooth surface, and its superior angles correspond to the ureteric openings, and the inferior angle corresponds to the internal urethral orifice. The bladder is extraperitoneal

options.label: a
options.text: is wider than the left

options.label: b
options.text: lies 40 degrees from the vertical

options.label: c
options.text: is longer than the left main bronchus

options.label: d
options.text: lies anterior to the SVC

options.label: e
options.text: is posterior to the right pulmonary artery

explanation: The right main bronchus is wider and shorter than the left, and the right main pulmonary artery runs anterior to it. The right main bronchus lies 20 degrees to the vertical, and the left bronchus lies 40 degrees to the vertical

options.label: a
options.text: is formed by the splenic artery and superior mesenteric artery

options.label: b
options.text: runs posterior to the first part of the duodenum

options.label: c
options.text: joins the IVC posterior to the common bile duct

options.label: d
options.text: is formed behind the body of the pancreas

options.label: e
options.text: is 5cm long

explanation: The portal vein is formed behind the neck of the pancreas by the union of the splenic and superior mesenteric vein. It then runs posterior to the first part of the duodenum and enters the lesser omentum to ascend to the porta hepatis

options.label: a
options.text: The epicondyles are intracapsular

options.label: b
options.text: The capitellum articulates with the radial head

options.label: c
options.text: The radial nerve lies in close relation to the diaphysis

options.label: d
options.text: The medial epicondyle is the flexor origin

options.label: e
options.text: The supraspinatus muscle attaches to the lesser tuberosity

explanation: The epicondyles are extracapsular. The medial epicondyle gives rise to the flexor origin, and the lateral epicondyle gives rise to the extensor origin

options.label: a
options.text: The ascending aorta lies anterior to the main pulmonary artery

options.label: b
options.text: All the main pulmonary artery is contained in the pericardium

options.label: c
options.text: At the pulmonary hilum the right superior pulmonary vein is antero-inferior to the right pulmonary artery

options.label: d
options.text: The right pulmonary artery lies anterior to the SVC

options.label: e
options.text: The left pulmonary artery passes anterior to the left main bronchus

explanation: The main pulmonary artery leaves the upper part of the right ventricle and is enclosed in a pericardial sheath with the ascending aorta. It terminates in the concavity of the arch of the aorta by dividing into the right and left pulmonary arteries. The right pulmonary artery is longer than the left and runs behind the ascending aorta and superior vena cava (SVC). It then runs anterior to the right main bronchus. The left pulmonary artery runs to the left in front of the left main bronchus and then spirals over the superior aspect of the left main bronchus
